pros: Great University to explore your talent and learn

pros: I feel that WIU offers the best medical insurance, vacation package, holiday compensation, and sick benefits you will find in this region. WIU offers a great work schedule for staff and administrators - 37.5 hours per week (8-4:30 with an hour lunch), which is great for family life.  Most employees at WIU have good values and are hard working.
cons:
The current upper management structure has many flaws due to it's extremely decentralized setup.  Typically, upper management doesn't know what the people under them do, which makes it difficult for them to adequately evaluate employees who others in the department know are not performing well; it also makes it difficult for management to make smart decisions in the current poor economic climate in Illinois.   Several employees do not perform strongly, yet management is unaware of the issues.   Due to managements lack of understanding of job flow of units, some areas are overstaffed and some are severely understaffed.

The pay is also well below industry averages for many positions (especially in technical fields), which makes it difficult to attract quality employees.  Pay raises have been almost non-existent for some time unless you are protected by a union.

pros: Flexible hours were very helpful.
cons: Student employee, so not many hours.

job_title: Software Engineer in Silver Spring, MD
pros:
Good work environment
It is a good place to study and work
cons: Little salary for TA position

pros: Great benefits and pay if you get the right job.
cons: None that I can think of

pros: The people here are wonderful.  It's a small town and everybody knows everybody else.  Most of the lower-level people are extremely hard working and at the same time, accommodating and warm.  The university work-life itself is great; you have an opportunity to learn new things every day, and the atmosphere is, on the surface, full of youth and vibrance.
cons: The State of Illinois is broke.  Expect to be paid far less than you are worth, and watch as incompetent managers stumble and fall all while getting endless promotions and back-patting...and then blaming on the underlings that warned them about it all along.  Enrollment here is declining, the infrastructure is crumbling due to lack of maintenance, and the administration does nothing but blame the people with the least control over things.

review_title: Good work/life balance but poor salary
job_title: Instructional Systems Technology Manager in Macomb, IL
pros: I enjoy the work, benefits and vacation time
cons: Poor salary or incentive.  I've worked at WIU for over 6 years and I've never been given the opportunity to advance or increase my salary.  I'm one of the more reliable and dedicated employees in my department.  I work with people who come in late (sometimes very late) and leave early.  I have a master's degree and I barely make $33K.  I have coworkers who don't do anything all day and they are making $60K - $70K.  It's really frustrating and management doesn't care.  I want to work hard for this institution but there is no incentive from management or the people above them.  Western Illinois University is a closed system.  You have to know people in high places to advance.

pros: The tasks assigned are not too difficult and provide opportunities to work with various members of the department. The stipend and tuition waiver make this job well worth having while being a grad student.
cons: Some of the staff does not do well with their own time management, which can sometimes make getting a project done take longer than needed. The employees should focus on being more time efficient instead of spending time talking about unrelated work topics.

pros: Good people doing the best job they can under tough financial times
cons: Administration missed a number of opportunities to reduce cost without cutting employees. Over 100 retires were replaced only to be followed up by layoffs. Building were remodeled at a high price tag (~$11M) when recommended previously by facility management to stop using building if not take it down due to deferred maintenance.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Moline, IL
pros: Although the stipend is not much, the free tuition benefit more than makes up for the low pay. This allowed me to get more than half of my MBA paid for by the school itself. The hours were very flexible and my fellow Assistants were great to work with. It was a very fun atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes the work could be a little dull. Grading could also be a little overwhelming at times. The stipend is also fixed, so there is no chance of a raise or added responsibilities.

review_title: Best place to work on campus for students!
pros: Constantly meeting new people, great place to network, great opportunity to hone in on interpersonal skills, astounding professionalism, great team cohesion, very comfortable setting, never feels too uptight!
cons: Dealing with constantly rude patrons may get overwhelming at times, as a supervisor, dealing with rude workers can be frustrating sometimes, sometimes there can be lack of communication between staff.

review_title: Nice Job to Raise a Family
pros: Excellent medical, vacation, and sick benefits.  Great work schedule for faculty, staff, and administrators - 37.5 hours per week for full-time staff is great for family life.
cons:
Management structure is VERY poor.  Management doesn't know what the people under them do, which makes it difficult for them to make wise, informed decisions.

Pay is also bad for many positions compared to national averages.

job_title: Front Desk Assistant in Macomb, IL
pros: Scheduling is based on your availability, you can do your homework during shifts, and you can stay during breaks work more hours.
cons: Since the desk is open 24hrs everyone will have to an overnight shift at some point. Co-workers can be unreliable and won't show up for shifts. Supervisors are grad students who can be too laid back which is nice but they are so wrap in their lives that employees aren't properly trained and Desk Captains do not nothing about it.

review_title: Better to have a tenure track position than adjunct forever
pros: Really low expectations for publications in order to obtain tenure.
cons: If you really want to teach and make a difference, you definitely can and your students will certainly appreciate it. but know that you might be teaching in a place where your colleagues tease you for actually liking your job because so many people are just miserable and "punching the clock"

review_title: Great Place to Work - State Budget is Killing Us
pros: Flexible, good benefits, I believe most people care deeply about the university and the direction it's heading.
cons: Budget, budget, budget!  Illinois has been terrible for at least the last ten years.  No we're looking at more layoffs, furloughs, possible wage and benefit cuts.

review_title: University doesn't serve students the way they deserve
pros: Small network, decent benefits package, employees like to have fun outside of the work, train to Chicago, students at the university will really open up to employees who can show they care
cons: Staff nickel and dimes students, all about making money, people in leadership have been so for too long, confusing work/life balance when seeing boss outside of work at all times

pros: Excellent health, dental, and vision benefits. Great vacation and sick time, especially as an exempt civil service employee. 28 days per year plus holidays and administrative closures (Christmas-New Year). Domestic partner benefits.
cons: Civil Service - Can be difficult to move up in position during times of fiscal crisis and when you are already at the top of your classification series. DO NOT select the traditional retirement when you start. Manage your own retirement so the state can't change your benefits mid-career!

pros:
Excellent benefits
Can take free classes every semester
cons:
WIU was once a wonderful place to work - that is no longer true. 
Dwindling enrollment due to mismanagement by administration and no budget for two years 
Major layoffs (including myself)
Cuts to programs
Buildings in disrepair
No raises in 5 years
Very stressful atmosphere - nobody knows if they will be the next to be cut.

pros: The environment is relatively friendly, the town is small but nice, and the salary is adequate for a small town with low cost of living.
cons: Communication is disappointing. Departments do not communicate with one another, with their own members, or with the administration. Nor does the administration do a very good job communicating with departments.

pros: Macomb is nice small town environment with Amtrak train to Chicago. Great faculty and excellent education opportunities for students. The education is first rate.
cons: Leadership has added and guards management. The number of levels of high paid managers is dragging the university down. Management does not have expertise nor the knowledge of front line employees who are experts in their field. Front line employees will always be first to be laid off, never management.

review_title: It was easy, exciting, and fulfilling to work for Western Illinois University.
pros:

Could easily get time off if requested before
Very close knit departments
cons:
Can be pretty dull fairly often
work loads would come in waves from being dead boring to super crunch time in a snap of a finger
They tried to force many older workers into early retirement
